Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic Studies on Rare and Novel Marine Diterpenes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis program is funding Professor Gary Sulikowski of the Department of Chemistry at Vanderbilt University to explore the development of synthetic methods to access structural complex and rare marine diterpene natural products. A number of complex marine diterpenes, such as bielschowskysin, display interesting biological activity (tumor cell growth inhibition, antimalarial properties), but are either no longer available from their natural source, or of limited availability. The unique molecular structure of bielschowskysin and related marine diterpenes requires the development of new methods and strategies to assemble its unique architecture.

The broader impacts include co-worker training in a multi-disciplinary environment through the inclusion of biomedical researchers on the project, and continuing to build a program in the biological study of natural products. This work could lead to more efficient methods for the preparation of marine natural products. The chemistry developed during the course of these studies will have a broad impact in areas ranging from the pharmaceutical, chemical, and biotechnology industries to basic biological and chemical research endeavors. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of students, from undergraduate to post-doctoral, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The furanocembranes are natural products isolated from marine coral, with many demonstrating important biological activity such as antitumor and antimalaria. However the natural products are often isolated in trace amounts and often not identified again as production by marine coral is complicated, often involving varaible microorganisms. For this reason and as a challenge to create new synthetic routes and chemistry, marine natural products are often selected as targets for chemical synthesis starting from readily available materials. The major natural product of interest to our group is bielschowskysin, a structurally interesting and no longe accessible natural product. Despite the efforts of over ten research groups from all over the world, bielschowskysin has never been prepared by chemical synthesis. Our approach utilizes a highly efficient photochemical reaction to product an entire half of the natural product. We are now developing efficient routes that will allow completely assembly of bielschowskysin for the first time. Completion of bileschowskysin will require we address two other critical synthetic transformations. First, a selective intramolecular aldol will provide the core of bielschowskysin. And second a series of controlled transformaitons will complete bielschowskysin itself.

Upon completion the natural product will be assayed for biological activity including antitumor and antimalarial activity by way of collaboration with biomedical investigators at Vanderbilt University. We also plan to assess advanced synthetic intermediates that contain many of the key structural features of this natural product.


Last Modified: 11/16/2015
Modified by: Gary Sulikowski
